message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Event-Based Finite-Time Control for Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Asymptotic Tracking
Paper Abstract: In this article, an adaptive neural finite-time event-triggered consensus tracking problem is studied for nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) under directed graphs. First, the unknown nonlinear functions of MASs can be approximated by neural networks. Then, a distributed adaptive event-triggered control scheme is proposed via command filter and backstepping technique. The newly designed control scheme cannot only circumvent the problem of the explosion of complexity, but also remove the singularity issue typical of conventional backstepping technique. In the meanwhile, an event-triggered mechanism with a dynamic threshold is devised to reduce the waste of network resources. Moreover, by using a novel finite-time stability criterion, it can be proved that the closed-loop system is finite-time stable and the consensus tracking errors can reach zero as time approaches to infinity. Finally, a numerical example is given to validate the feasibility of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "directed graphs":

## Overview

A directed graph (or digraph) is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by directed edges, often called arcs.(no content)In formal terms, a directed graph is an ordered pair G = (V, A) where V is a set whose elements are called vertices, nodes, or points; A is a set of ordered pairs of vertices, called arcs, directed edges, arrows, or directed lines.

## Key Characteristics

It differs from an ordinary or undirected graph, in that the latter is defined in terms of unordered pairs of vertices, which are usually called edges, links or lines.

## Types of Directed Graphs

Several important variants of directed graphs exist:

- **Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)**: A directed acyclic graph (DAG) is a directed graph with no directed cycles—it consists of vertices and edges, with each edge directed from one vertex to another, such that following those directions will never form a closed loop.

- **Symmetric directed graphs**: Symmetric directed graphs are directed graphs where all edges appear twice, one in each direction.

- **Weighted directed graphs**: Weighted directed graphs (also known as directed networks) are (simple) directed graphs with weights assigned to their arrows.

## Applications

For instance, the link structure of a website can be represented by a directed graph, in which the vertices represent web pages and directed edges represent links from one page to another.(no content)DAGs have numerous scientific and computational applications, ranging from biology (evolution, family trees, epidemiology) to information science (citation networks) to computation (scheduling).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Adaptive Control - Search Results

Here's what I found about adaptive control:

### General Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Difference from Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Technical Foundation

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

### Main Approaches

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

### Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Strict-feedback form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strict-feedback_form"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Back mount - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_mount"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping is a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)It is one of several nonlinear control techniques that typically takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Key Characteristics

Systems in strict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping. A simplified way to understand it: backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## Historical Context

Petar V. Kokotovic made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Web search results for query: "neural networks"

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(biology)"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Mathematics of neural networks in machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_neural_networks_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"}]

I've performed a web search for "neural networks" and found comprehensive information. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## What are Neural Networks?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure and Architecture

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Historical Context

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Katia Sycara - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katia_Sycara"},{"title":"Peter Stone (professor) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Stone_(professor)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Wassim Michael Haddad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wassim_Michael_Haddad"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multiagent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Components and Characteristics

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

Key characteristics include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Research Areas

The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about event-triggered control in the context of control systems and research. Here's what I found:

Event-triggered control is a research area where Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, received IEEE Fellow recognition in 2016 for his contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

While the search results don't provide a comprehensive definition of event-triggered control specifically, the context suggests it's an important concept in control systems engineering, particularly related to networked and hybrid systems. Event-triggered control typically refers to a control strategy where control actions are triggered by specific events (such as when a system state crosses a threshold) rather than being executed on a fixed time schedule—contrasting with time-triggered approaches.

If you're looking for more detailed technical information about event-triggered control methods, specific applications, or theoretical foundations, I'd be happy to search for more specialized resources on this topic.

Web search results for query: "finite-time stability control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Exponential stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_exponent"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"}]

Based on the search results, I found information about control systems and stability, though the results contain general information about stability concepts rather than a specific dedicated article on finite-time stability. Here's what I found:

## General Stability Concepts in Control Systems

In asymptotically stable control systems, variables always decrease from their initial value and do not show permanent oscillations. This represents the traditional approach to stability analysis.

However, the search results do mention a related concept: Solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times due to finite escape time, which relates to the temporal aspectsof system behavior that finite-time stability addresses.

## Lyapunov Stability Methods

A more general method for analyzing stability involves Lyapunov functions, which are fundamental tools used in control systems analysis and can be extended to finite-time stability analysis.

## Key Takeaway

While the search results don't contain a dedicated article specifically focused on finite-time stability control systems, they provide foundational concepts about control system stability. Finite-time stability is a specialized topic that extends classical stability theory to guarantee that system trajectories converge to equilibrium in finite time, rather than asymptotically over infinite time. This is particularly important for practical applications where convergence speed is critical.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Lyapunov stability:

## Definition and Concept

Lyapunov stability means that near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state x≠0 in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.(no content)Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Historical Background

Based on the search results, I found information about "consensus tracking control," which appears to be a topic at the intersection of control theory and multi-agent systems.

## Overview

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Core Concepts

The consensus problem in multi-agent systems aims to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)The consensus protocol, or agreement protocol, defines the rules of interaction that lead to convergence.(no content)Related coordination problems include the rendezvous problem, synchronization, flocking, and formation control, which often rely on similar mathematical foundations and are studied under the broader umbrella of cooperative control.

This field combines control theory principles with the challenge of coordinating multiple autonomous agents to achieve agreement or synchronization in distributed systems.

Web search results for query: "nonlinear control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear control systems:

## Definition and Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle, and it applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems differ fundamentally from linear systems in several ways:

- These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.
- They may have multiple isolated equilibrium points and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, chaos.
- Solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times (finite escape time).

## Analysis and Design Techniques

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.(no content)Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems. The approach involves transforming a nonlinear control system into an equivalent linear control system through a change of variables and a suitable control input.

## Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off." The furnace is off until the temperature falls below the "turn on" setpoint of the thermostat, when it turns on. Due to the heat added by the furnace, the temperature increases until it reaches the "turn off" setpoint of the thermostat, which turns the furnace off, and the cycle repeats.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** contribution (the paper proposes novel control schemes and mechanisms)

**Key Triples Extracted:** 10 triples covering the core technologies and methodologies

The analysis identified the following key technologies and concepts:

1. **Multi-agent system** - The core problem domain
2. **Neural network (machine learning)** - Used for approximating nonlinear functions
3. **Directed graph** - Represents agent communication topology
4. **Adaptive control** - Enables system adaptation to uncertainties
5. **Backstepping** - Nonlinear control technique employed
6. **Nonlinear control** - Foundational theory for the approach
7. **Lyapunov stability** - Used for stability analysis
8. **Consensus dynamics** - Theoretical framework for agent agreement
9. **Control theory** - Mathematical foundation
10. **Event-driven architecture** - Novel mechanism proposed for reducing network resource waste

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the JSON structure meets all requirements:
- Paper properly classified as "contribution"
- At least 1 "uses" relation (all papers build on existing work) ✓
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (contribution papers create something new) ✓
- All entity types correctly assigned
- All Wikipedia URLs valid
